DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Vanstone proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to give real priority to the issue of youth unemployment.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some regret that I raise this matter for discussion in the Senate today. As the youngest senator I felt compelled in my maiden speech to address the disillusionment of young Australians. Such disillusionment is one of the greatest problems facing this nation. Youth unemployment is an enormous problem. But the disillusionment created therefrom is, in my view, a greater problem. When the youth of a country lose direction, hope and spirit, a dark and gloomy shadow is cast over the fabric of that society. In my State the youth unemployment rate is the highest rate in the mainland States. There are 2,200 more young unemployed than there were when John Bannon, the Labor Premier, took office. The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, in Question Time today gave us a dose of figures. But I assure her they are cold comfort to those young Australians who are currently unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: We all remember the glossy television announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on what is called Priority One. The silver budgie, as some call our Prime Minister, delivered a masterpiece of presentation. The program was produced by students of the Swinburne Institute of Technology. It was a hard sell, with all the sincerity of the Coca Cola commerical, but it was not the real thing; it was a mirage. It was a statesmanlike speech, but that was the easy part. The real work is yet to be done and, what is worse, it had not been done when the Prime Minister delivered his eulogy. Michelle Grattan, a well respected political commentator, obviously perceives the reality of this expedient Government-a government that has elevated pragmatism above principle in an attempt to ensure its political survival. In the Age of 19 August she stated:
The Government is now looking expectantly to youth policy to strengthen its reform credentials when it goes to the next election.

The headline of that article reads: `Government looks to youth for a revival'. It should have read: `Government looks to youth for survival'. This Government will do anything to win a vote. Six months ago its number one priority was to put the tax system in order. We all know what a mess it has made of that and how far it has gone with that goal. Whatever may be the personal evangelistic crusade of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), this Prime Minister and this Government embrace causes, not from any concern for the merit of the cause, but with a desire to generate publicity and headlines and to create an impression. They have sought to create the impression that the problems of youth unemployment are their number one priority. In fact, as an article in the Bulletin makes clear, the so-called Priority One program is a public relations exercise. It refers to it as the `Hawke strategy for survival'.

We should ask ourselves why the Prime Minister chose to announce this program in a Sunday night spectacular prior to the Budget being delivered. The answer is simple. The Prime Minister has an insatiable appetite for media coverage and has sought to give himself precedence in this matter over his hard working Treasurer. How unkind to raise the expectations of young Australians when, at the time that the announcement was made, the groundwork in not one industry had been completed. Mr Peter Kirby, the architect of the scheme, expressed his regret that the announcement had been made without such an agreement. He went on to say that it would have been preferable for the Government's statement to have been accompanied by agreements between unions and industry.

The unions have given only qualified support to this scheme. Mr Bill Kelty, the Australian Council of Trade Unions Secretary, warned that nervous unions would not support any erosion of junior award conditions. The unions have given only qualified support to this number one priority. This Government's dependence upon a compliant ACTU means that the silver budgie, trapped in his ACTU cage, will sing whatever song this vested interest dictates. If the ACTU backs off from its already limited commitment, so will this Government.
Mr Dawkins, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, has some news at which, I understand, young Australians are expected to be ecstatic. He says:
But I would be very surprised if we couldn't get agreement to a trainee wage of about the order of $90.

Is that not wonderful news? He will be surprised if the Government cannot get that agreement. Let me assure him that if that agreement is not secured, young Australians will not be surprised; they will be more fed up, more disillusioned and more frustrated, and they have every right to be so. The Government has created the impression that the problems of young Australia are about to be taken in hand and solved. But young Australians are about to be disillusioned yet again.

The Government has made extravagant claims. Lest anyone should think I am being unfair to a government that has good intentions, I ask honourable senators to turn their minds to a recent article in the Australian, headlined `Willis claims traineeships will halve youth jobless'. The text of the article indicates that Mr Willis said he thought the scheme would halve the unemployment rate amongst 16 to 17-year-olds. He did not say what would happen to 18, 19, 20 and 21-year-olds. How disgraceful to suggest to young Australians that their problems are nearly over. How deplorable to raise in their minds the expectation that instead of one in four being unemployed, it will soon be one in eight.

Much reliance in the Priority One program is placed on formal technical and further education training. I ask what the Government has to say about the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development report into Australian youth policies and its comments on TAFE. I quote from the report:

. . . the team . . . did not find convincing evidence that (i) TAFE was already effective in providing technical training and education . . . or (ii) expansion of TAFE capacity would yield more of a payoff than if, for example, the resources needed for such an expansion were devoted to secondary education or the support of enterprise-based training.

Given those comments, the Government should now explain how TAFE will cope with the increased demand that Priority One will put on it before it invokes TAFE training as a panacea for unemployment. This is no way for a government to discharge its responsibility to young Australians. How cynical for this Government to announce this scheme when the groundwork has not been completed. Mr Michael Clohessy, the Executive Director of the Youth Affairs Council of Australia, is concerned that little has been said about supervising the traineeships. He stated:

The Department of Employment and Industrial Relations has total responsibility for the traineeships and we know that Department has a very dubious record in actually delivering anything for young people.

The Government has failed to appreciate the real problems of youth unemployment. If we acknowledge the real causes we can find real solutions. The Government seems determined to reject the suggestion that inflexibility in the labour market, particularly in youth wages, is a fundamental cause of youth unemployment. It is keen to say, as did Mr Willis, that the Priority One scheme is not a back door means of reducing youth wages. What is it, if it is not an acknowledgement of the cost to the employer of training young people? Surely we are not to believe that this cost is incurred only with formal on the job training. Surely, even Blind Freddy can see that there is a cost involved in employing people who have no experience or training, because they must be given some training even if only informally. This cost can be acknowledged by government subsidy, as under Priority One, or it could be done more simply, more efficiently and with less public sector interference by freeing up youth wages.

Every government subsidy scheme is an admission that rigidities in the wage system are keeping our young people out of jobs. It is extraordinary for a government that denies that high youth wages are keeping young people out of jobs to write to the Premiers of the States, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did, to open negotiations on waiving or reducing State payroll taxes. If this is not an admission that the cost of employing young people is too high, what is? Another premature announcement was that Mr Dawkins, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, was reported as being hopeful-hopeful, all honourable senators will be pleased to note-that all State governments will agree to the remission of payroll tax and workers compensation charges for people under 21 years.

I am somewhat at a loss to see how State governments can remit workers compensation charges which in reality are paid to insurance companies. I can only presume that the Prime Minister is hoping that the States will waive stamp duty as it applies in various States. I challenge the Government to release this correspondence to the Premiers and to make public the details of any responses it has had. How far down the track is the Government in getting the agreement it seeks with the States? This scheme, masquerading as a sincere move under the label `Priority One: Young Australia' is really just another scheme to subsidise employment in the public sector.

It has been reported that government sources privately concede that the bulk of traineeships will be in the public sector. How far has this Government reached in agreements with private sector employers? I challenge the Government to come clean. How many employers have agreed to participate? How many traineeships have been established in the private sector? In which States and when did or when will those traineeships commence? The trainee schemes are meant to involve industries such as banking, retailing, tourism and hospitality. I ask: How is the small businessman and the small employer-the backbone of this country-going to be able to participate in these schemes?

We are told that committees are going to be set up in each State. Eventually this will happen and these committees will provide training kits for these employers. I challenge the Government to tell honourable senators in which States and for what industries these committees have already been set up. I challenge it further to provide the names of the people who are the members and the date of appointment of each member. All this work has yet to be done. The resolution of the problems of young Australians is some way down the track. However, none of that stopped the silver budgie from grabbing the headlines, having his Sunday spectacular and unfairly raising the expectations of young Australians. This Government is lying to young Australians. It has packaged up some ideas and called the package Priority One: Young Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I think there has been a reflection on an honourable member of the other place in what Senator Vanstone has been saying. The further point of order I am taking is that the speech is being read.
—Oh, boy!

—I am sorry, but I am going to raise it now because I wish to attract the attention of the Senate to a practice that is developing in this place of people coming in here with prepared speeches and reading those prepared speeches.
—I have got your point of order. Your point of order is that Senator Vanstone is reading her speech.
—Yes.
—I do not need anything further.
—Let me put the point of order on this basis-
—There is no requirement for a speech. If there is anything further that you wish to draw to my attention, you may do so, but do not make a speech about it.

—I suggest to you, with great respect, that I should be allowed to support the point of order I am making so that the Chair realises that I feel strongly about it. I just want to make the position clear that we have had developed in this new Senate the practice of practically everyone in this place reading their speeches. That is contrary to the Standing Orders, is not in the best interests of the senators concerned and is not in the best interests of the Senate.

—Order! I have got the point of order. Senator Vanstone, it is not in order to call the Prime Minister a silver budgie and that remark should be withdrawn. You should not read your speech. I cannot tell from here whether you are or not, but by looking up fairly frequently you will indicate that you are not reading your speech. Will you withdraw your reference to the Prime Minister?

—Mr Deputy President, I withdraw the reference to the Prime Minister being a silver budgie. The Government would have us believe that the scheme that it calls Priority One is an organised and planned way of approaching the problems of youth unemployment. According to the Government this scheme warranted full page and double page advertisements in the major daily papers throughout Australia. What did we see in those advertisements? We saw the Prime Minister's picture and a message that was meant to assure young Australians that their problems had become this Government's No. 1 priority. Through you, Mr Deputy President, I ask honourable senators to turn their minds back to those advertisements. If they do so they will remember that there was no telephone number, no department and no place young Australians could contact anybody to find out the details of what the Government was prepared to do for them. It is my submission that this was a disgraceful waste of government money and it was a disgraceful thing to do-to advertise that the problems of young unemployed Australians are the Government's No. 1 priority when in fact its program is in such a mess and is so inadequately prepared that it cannot tell young Australians where to go to get the help that it is allegedly offering.

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line of this scheme is that it contains no ideas, no mechanism and no guarantee that jobs will be there at the end of these training schemes for young unemployed Australians. The net result of what the Government has done is to have raised the expectations of young people in a callous and brutal way. It has expediently chased electoral popularity and at the end of it all there is no guarantee of real relief for young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just witnessed the unedifying spectacle of a member of the Opposition trying to justify the patently false and ludicrous assertion, as set out in the proposal under standing order 64-the failure of the Government to give real priority to the issue of youth unemployment. I have no problem in admitting that I read the last few lines because I could not believe it even if I had to remember it. The proposition presented by the Opposition is patently false and there is essentially one argument only that needs to be expressed to prove it. That argument is simply that the Opposition's economic philosophy-that described as being of the dry variety-is a philosophy that one fights inflation first.

SPEECH.PARA: During the whole of the period of the Fraser Government-a period when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer and when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Neil Brown, was Minister for Employment-we saw an overwhelming explosion of unemployment. The worst affected section was the young people of Australia because that Government fought inflation first by lengthening the dole queues to force down market rates of wage. That was the strategy that was employed during the Fraser years. That is the strategy that the Opposition is economically committed to now. Were it ever, God help us, to assume government in this country, we would be facing once again the spectacle of increasing unemployment while the Opposition applied its economically blinkered ideology about how the economy should be run. That is the proposition which comes from an opposition committed to that philosophy. It is ludicrous and it is patently false.

We have heard in the speech by Senator Vanstone nothing at all that is new. It has been merely a carping criticism of a positive, progressive and inspired campaign by this Government to give the youth of Australia a role in society and to develop through the youth of this country a more diversified skill base in the work force and some hope for the future. We have developed a positive program. (Quorum formed)

We have just witnessed opposition by assertion. The real priority of this Government is youth and youth programs. This Government has declared that as a priority and has introduced a positive program which will apply for the next three years. The program commenced as at the recent Budget. It is a program that gives real hope and a real future to the young people of Australia. It is assigned the highest priority by the Government. It is a program led by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and supported by a task force of members of Cabinet comprising the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs, Mr Dawkins; the Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan; and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ralph Willis. It is a program aimed at giving careers, futures and hope to the young people of Australia. As I have said, this is the first year of the program. Since the 1960s at least, the level of youth unemployment has been two or three times higher than the general level. While overall unemployment was growing up until 1983, youth unemployment grew faster. Similarly, it is falling faster now that overall unemployment is declining. From August 1984 to August 1985 youth unemployment fell from 25.1 per cent to 21.6 per cent while overall unemployment fell from 8.9 per cent to 8.3 per cent. This indicates that even when unemployment falls to 5 per cent youth unemployment is still likely to be well over 10 per cent.

The Government is not content with the improvement being brought about by its macroeconomic policies. Therefore, it has developed a series of other policies aimed at providing a balanced attack on youth unemployment in order that the real needs of the young unemployed are met. Our balanced attack consists of the Priority One: Young Australia program which has three major strands-an educative strand, which is aimed at encouraging higher retention rates, better targeting for skills, better targeting for all round education and a better qualified work force; a strand dealing with labour market programs, the key feature of which is the traineeship scheme and a number of other schemes; and a strand dealing with rationalising and bringing together the question of youth allowances to provide a better base and a better understanding of how youth allowances operate in this country.

I will deal with each one of those strands as a logical component of the whole by providing some explanation about them. Our traineeship program is a genuine effort to come to grips with a hole in the labour market. Because of recession in the past, falling applications for apprenticeships, the emergence and change in the types of skills and the emergence of different types of industry, there are now gaps. There are not enough sufficiently qualifield or trained workers to apply for jobs, particularly in the retail, finance, tourism and hospitality industries. It is not appropriate to develop in those areas a fully fledged apprenticeship program at this stage. Therefore, the Government has supported, as the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs recommended, a system of traineeships which is not a means of reducing youth wages but a system of providing a work based traineeship with off the job training through tertiary and further education for young unemployed. We target, by 1988-89, 75,000 traineeships in existence. In the first year our target is for 10,000 traineeships. As I have said, the industries involved are the growth industries of retail, finance, tourism and hospitality. The Commonwealth has undertaken to provide 20 per cent of those traineeships. We expect that the State governments will pick up their share as well.

The traineeships scheme involves different categories of subsidies to employers ranging from $1,000 to $2,000 per year per employee. In 1985-86 this will also be backed up by increased course development grants and allowance for greater mobility of the work force. The value of the Government's contribution in this Budget is $15.7m. In rising to our target of 75,000 jobs for young unemployed under traineeship schemes in 1988-89, the commitment of the Commonwealth, in association with the States, will be of the order of $250m to $300m. So it is not a scheme that does not come to grips with the real dimensions of the problem. It is a scheme which transforms the fundamental labour market for the young unemployed and gives them a chance to compete with skills, training and experience which they need to hold their place in the general work force.

On the education front, what this Government inherited was best illustrated by a comprehensive answer by Senator Ryan to a question in Question Time. Our participation rate was the worst in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. Of all the OECD countries in the period 1975 to 1980, Australia had a participation rate for 15- to 19-year-olds of 44.4 per cent when the OECD average was 57 per cent. In 1980, for that same age category, our participation rate rose to only 46.2 per cent when the OECD average went to 62.4 per cent. For the higher age group-20- to 24-year-olds-the discrepancies were even more remarkable. This Government inherited a situation in education in which people were dropping out of the system much more quickly. They were not holding their places. They were turning out into the work force undereducated for the demands that employers were placing upon them.

Over the next three years this Government is committed to increasing funds for education with a new system of per capita recurrent grants which will increase school funding so that funding for secondary schools in the 1985-88 triennium goes up by 57 per cent in real terms. Funding for primary schools will go up by 16 per cent in real terms. There is a big commitment to improving the quality of education that is delivered. At the tertiary level, our programs mean that through TAFE there will be 15,000 extra places in the 1985-87 period. Through universities and colleges of advanced education 20,500 places, an increase of 7.6 per cent, will be made available, with special attention to disadvantaged groups. There is a commitment to curricula content and the development of curricula through the Curriculum Development Centre and to the participation and equity program within the Commonwealth Schools Commission. In the last two years of our Government we have improved participation rates significantly. I would refer to Senator Ryan's answer to a question rather than cite the figures.

In terms of income support for young unemployed workers, when we came to government there were 37 different Commonwealth programs of support in areas of education, training and social security. We have embarked upon a comprehensive review of those programs and have identified the differences in the levels of payment. In the income testing arrangements we have made assumptions about what support parents are providing or are not providing for young workers, the independence of young workers from their parents, and assumptions about the needs of young workers in different activities. The basis for our rationalising of income support for young workers is that the age of the individual is important, rather than the type of activity, and that all of the allowances ought to be cast at such a level as to be adequate to meet their needs. This rationalised payment structure will be phased in over the next three years, commencing in 1986, with increases in all major educational allowances, particularly for secondary students, and most unemployment benefit payments.

By 1989 the new age-related structure of allowances will be fully in place and thereafter will be indexed in line with movements in the consumer price index. Three basic common rates will be payable-for 16- to 17-year-olds, whether in secondary or tertiary education or unemployed; for unemployed 18- to 20-year-olds and tertiary students aged 18 and over who are independent or living away from home; and for students aged 18 and over living at home. Next year, the maximum benefits payable under the secondary allowance scheme will rise from $23 to $35 a week while the rate of unemployment benefit for 16- to 17-year-olds will be increased from $45 to a common $50 a week. Secondary allowances will then be allowed to catch up to the benefit rate and both will become subject to annual indexation from January 1988. A similar process of transition is envisaged for payments under the tertiary allowances scheme which, for those aged 18 years and over living away from home, will progressively approach what will become an intermediate rate of unemployment benefit for 18- to 20-year-olds. This is currently $85 a week. The net cost of these reforms is estimated at $35m in 1985-86, rising progressively to a full year cost of $250m in 1988-89.

We have taken a positive and direct approach to the problems of youth on those three fronts in a comprehensive package marshalled under the leadership of the Prime Minister, with the input of the key Ministers responsible for education, youth affairs, employment and industrial relations. It is a three-year program. It is in its first year and answers a real need. That is our positive program. That program has been attacked by the Opposition with trite criticisms, carping innuendoes and a dog in the manger approach. What is striking about the Opposition's participation in this debate so far is: What has the Opposition put forward? In government its members presided over the highest unemployment rate this country has ever seen, and the highest unemployment rate for young unemployed.

The Opposition has put forward the pathetic assertion that if one cuts youth wages, somehow blaming the young unemployed for their plight, one will increase the number of jobs. Opposition senators fail to recognise that even during the period of the Fraser Government Administrat- ion, the Bureau of Labour Market Research was enjoined by that Government to conduct a survey to try to make a causal link between cutting wages and creating jobs. That bureau, after a full and thorough study, was unable to make the connection. The assertion that if one cuts youth wages one will create more jobs is a piece of ideological claptrap that the Opposition believes, with no empirical evidence to support it. As long as the Opposition believes it, it will perpetuate the myth that if one blames the young for their plight, if one penalises the young by reducing the level of their income, one will somehow solve the problem. That is not the case. If youth wages are cut there might be a temporary change in employment patterns for the young at the cost of adults who will be pushed out of the system. When the young get to that age, they too will be sacked and dismissed.

The sort of employment scenario that the Opposition wishes to propound is that one employs cheap labour, sacks adults who are bread winners and family supporters, and thus create a situation in which when the young get older they, too, go on the scrap heap. That is not a humane system and it has no future because it does not involve any commitment to the training of skills. The old approach of `Blame the victims' is the approach of the old government. It is not an approach that this Government in any way supports. I have said quite clearly that there is no empirical evidence to support the assertion that merely by cutting wages one will create more employment. Let me go to a quotation from the comment column of the Age on 23 January this year. Claude Forell, under the heading `Youth wages and unemployment', said:

As the `Business Age' columnist, The Analyst, pointed out in a detailed examination on 31 December, international comparisons do not support the theory of a strong causal link between youth wages rates and unemployment.

In France, for example, youth wages are much lower in relation to adult wages than in Australia, but the youth unemployment rate is higher. In the United States, on the other hand, youth wage rates are relatively higher but the rate of youth unemployment is lower than in Australia.

That is empirical evidence. It would seem to be the obverse of what is being asserted by the Opposition. Once again I draw attention to the fact that merely to adopt the approach of blaming the victims, of trying to reduce wages and to change the cost component, does not answer the fact that employers want skilled, qualified labour with some experience in the operations required. Therefore, we have promoted the traineeship program to engender that sort of situation. We do not deny in any way that there is a severe problem with youth employment. We assert that it is not our fault; we inherited it. We have certainly done a lot to cause it to change. At present more than 19 per cent of teenagers in the labour force are unemployed; 23 per cent of those under 18 are unemployed. They participate in a secondary labour market-that is, in the low paid part time or casual jobs, jobs that can be easily replaced by technological change. That problem can only be addressed by equipping them with the skills to move into the first part of the labour market. With general economic recovery over the last two years, the Government has been able to increase teenage employment by 32,000 new positions or by 5.5 per cent-that is, since June 1983. It reverses the trend of the Fraser Government, and it means that at least half those 32,000 were new full time jobs. In the last two years apprenticeship placements have gone up 43 per cent.

In concluding my remarks I make the point that in focusing directly on programs affecting youth and their employment prospects, what should be remembered as the bottom line is that one cannot solve the youth unemployment problem unless there is general economic growth and improvement. This Government has been able to achieve ongoing growth of 5 per cent year on year. The Government is in a position of being able to achieve, too, its target of half a million jobs in the first three years. It is well ahead of that target. It has been able to lift the investment patterns in the general economy and therefore, because the macro-economic settings are right, we are in a climate in which employment generally is changing and improving. The youth programs we have enunciated will target and deal with expressly those issues for youth unemployment. The Opposition proposal is preposterous and I do not believe, in any sense, can be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just witnessed the depressing spectacle of honourable senators on both sides of this chamber accusing each other of causing youth unemployment. The facts are that youth unemployment has risen at a frightening rate over the last 10 years and both sides of this House, both Labor and Liberals, are responsible. During the last election one could not get a debate on youth unemployment because of an unholy alliance between the two major parties that youth unemployment was not a thing to be talked about. The fact is that there are 270,000 young people unemployed in our society today-that is, 15 per cent unemployed against an average unemployment rate of 8.1 per cent. If one looks at the age group of 25 to 65, the unemployment rate is only 6.5 per cent. It is clear that the young people are carrying the can for the malaise in our society. The fact that there are some 270,000 young people out of a total unemployment of 594,000 makes it very clear that the young people are indeed carrying the can.

SPEECH.PARA: This is having a devastating effect on these people. They are being cast aside. They are applying for job after job and being told that they are not wanted. Their morale is destroyed; their outlook on society is affected for all time; and they are being forced into prostitution, drug addiction, alcoholism and are being abused in other ways by society. They are losing their self-esteem and being refused participation in our society materially, culturally and academically. Many reasons have been put forward in the debate so far, and no doubt many more will be heard, as to why youth unemployment is so high. The Senate has been told that youth wages are too high, and that is a reason. We have also been told that the education system is not coping, and that is a reason. We have also been told-or if we have not been told already we will be told before the debate finishes-that young people are too lazy and are not prepared to work any more. I suggest that none of these reasons is the true reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who will say that? No one has said that.

—I am sure that it will be said before this debate is finished. The true reason, without a doubt, is the way the economy is operating. One has to look at the economy to find the true reasons for youth unemployment. The facts are that employers today no longer need young untrained, unskilled people. If an employer wants an inexperienced person, he goes straight to school and gets a school leaver. Those who have left school and who were unable to get a job straight away keep applying for jobs. When they are asked `What is your experience?', they reply, `I have none', and are therefore told `We don't want you'.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a lot of talk. There has been virtually no action and there is still, as far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, no positive solution to this problem. Youth unemployment has got to be solved now, not in a year's time or two years time when the economy may or may not pick up. I am afraid that the much vaunted Government training scheme will still not solve the problem. There is nothing more devastating to young people than to be trained for a job and at the end of that training to be discarded again by society and to be told that there are no jobs available. The Government's initiative is not getting at the heart of the problem.

In the short time available to me, I propose to outline a practical scheme that will solve youth unemployment problems straight away. This scheme allows the available work to be shared amongst the unemployed straight away. I have outlined this scheme in great detail. Later today, if the Senate allows me, I will table the details of the scheme that I will only briefly mention now. I am a little concerned that the Senate may not allow me to table this scheme. The reasons that I have been given are: `It is a little new. We have not quite seen a procedure for tabling details of a scheme like this before'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—There have been discussions along these lines this morning. I will be seeking leave to table a practical scheme that tackles youth unemployment head on and solves it straight away. Later today we will see whether the Senate is prepared to consider a practical scheme that relates to the 270,000 people out there who have been discarded by our society.

SPEECH.PARA: Four years ago I was approached by a social worker by the name of Bernie Geary who was concerned about motivating young people in the West Heidelberg area. He was living with them. These people had dropped out of society. Many of them were illiterate. They had decided that work was not for them. We decided that we would make a work station available to these young people which would be worked on a roster basis. Bernie Geary took the responsibility of manning the roster scheme. That scheme worked successfully for three years. Not one part of the roster scheme was missed in three years. That is an amazing record when we consider that these people were at the bottom of the heap. They had decided to give society away and never to work again. They found that a permanent part time job was all that was required to give them a completely new outlook on life. They had the discipline of working for a day or half a day a week. They became a part of a work force. They were doing a worthwhile job, not a make believe job or training job. They were performing a function that was necessary and the discipline and the opportunity to be a part of a team was all that was necessary to motivate these people to look for permanent work.

Surely that approach, which has been proven to work, is an approach that can solve the problem straight away. We can, if we want to, offer permanent part time work, not work experience for two months. At the end of two months of training young people are looking over a precipice. There is gloom-nothing. We tell them to go back to school to learn new skills without giving them any guarantee that at the end of that time they will have employment. We simply have to say to business: `Before employing anybody else, we require you to make at least one position available to be worked on a roster basis'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Simply said, what guarantee is there that they will listen or do anything?

—The Government has powers under the corporations, powers of the Constitution and other powers to require enterprises to make a work station available to be worked on a roster basis before they employ anybody else. They could employ four young people instead of just one. If all enterprises did that throughout Australia at least everybody who is out of work and looking for work would find a permanent part time job. The scheme can work very simply through the local community youth support scheme groups. They can relate to young people. A supervisor of a work station should be put in direct contact with the local CYSS group. This means that he does not have to go through third parties or worry about personnel officers and the like. The supervisor should be sympathetic and prepared to listen to the problems of young people in their search for work that most suits their abilities. He should get them started.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen this scheme in operation in Victoria in quite a few industries. It is working very well in those industries that have taken the trouble to concern themselves about this very real problem in our society. There is no need for retrenchments of the people who are working. We are saying that as positions become available we should worry about the youth first. We are not trying to employ young people at lower wages; we are saying: `Employ them at the current rates for casual work applicable to the age group concerned'. So there is no need to try to break the law of the land and to get people working in conditions and for wages that are below the award requirements in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should make some distinction between part time and casual employment; there are differences.

—I am simply suggesting that we want to give these unemployed young people a start in the real world-in the work force. That is all we are doing. Unless we have a practical scheme that allows this to happen these people will never get a job. What hope has a young person who cannot read or write? Unfortunately, for whatever reason, there are large numbers of these people around. They apply to the personnel officer. He says: `What is your name and address? Write it on this form'. They cannot, so they have got no hope. They are discards forever. People come with all kinds of hangups-maybe they are not physically attractive or they may have a chip on their shoulder about something. They apply to the personnel officer. He takes one look at them and says `They are not for us. My job is to pick the best, to get the best I can'. The personnel officer's job is not to concern himself about the youth unemployment problem. We have to break through the traditional ways of giving young people jobs. The only way to do that is to spread the available work and to put an organisation which is sympathetic to the problems of young people-I suggest most CYSS groups around Australia are sympathetic-in direct contact with a supervisor who is sympathetic to the problems of youth and prepared to give young people a go. That is the scheme. It could be applied overnight if the Government wished to do so. It would not cost the employer very much. The cost to the employer simply is that he has got to put a little more effort into training the young people. That is the only cost. Instead of training one person, the supervisor has to train four people. In an organisation with which I have very close associations I have seen this scheme work. The supervisor has been able to train these young people and to do his work as well. So there has been no additional cost at all.
—Is that in your company?

—Yes, indeed, in our company. It has been working successfully for some years. Many of the young people who have started off as part time employees have found full time employment with our company but, more importantly, they have been able to go to people at the available jobs and say: `I have a job with company X. I am employed'. That is an enormous advantage to these young people.
—Does that create more work?
—They have a permanent job. That is the important point.
—Order! Senator Siddons, will you please address your remarks through the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I could not hear the remarks properly anyway. I believe that if the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) took the trouble to check with his Department he would find there is a great deal of support for a scheme of this sort; it is a practical scheme which solves the youth unemployment problem now.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot sit back any longer and congratulate ourselves-as I am afraid the Government is attempting to do-on the fact that unemployment is dropping. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Vanstone on raising the following matter of public importance today:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to give real priority to the issue of youth unemployment.

Much in the recent spate of announcements of both Federal and State governments on youth unemployment smacks of political opportunism rather than genuine attempts to help young people. Youth unemployment remains a major problem. According to the August figures 21.6 per cent of teenagers were unemployed and looking for work. On my calculations that is 180,000 young Australians. It is a highly emotive problem and so it should be. Not only is this figure staying up but also the period during which young people remain unemployed is lengthening. The social and economic costs of a generation of young unemployed are enormous. In a country with a small population and the great natural advantages that Australia has, it should simply not occur. That it does occur is to the discredit of all of us.

Instead of having sound policies for youth the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), as honourable senators will recall, made a nationally televised address for the primary purpose of promoting his Government. We recall the circumstances after the farce of the National Taxation Summit when the Prime Minister demanded of his handlers an emotive issue, something which would touch people's hearts-and what better issue is there than youth unemployment? I will argue in the short time allowed for me to speak that he so compromised principle by political expediency-that is balancing the trilogy of big government, big business and big unions-that his package will fail to hit the target of those genuinely needing help. It is worth mentioning in passing the definition of a trilogy-a tragedy in three parts-because it seems apt to these circumstances. The Prime Minister's political opportunism pales into insignificance when compared with the political cynicism of State Labor Premiers in their desperate bid to hold office. In my State of South Australia Premier Bannon, who spent some $350,000 of taxpayers' money promoting a dressed-up portion of the Commonwealth package as his own initiative, must head the bill. The State Government called its adaptation `YES' and I suggest that, YES, it is a confidence trick at the expense of the young.

As we know, the heart of the Federal Government's proposal is traineeships. The Government will offer employers $1,000 to train a youth for at least one year. The employee must take at least 13 weeks off-the-job training. If the unions will co-operate he will be paid less than the minimum award wage. I say `if the unions will co-operate' because the announcement was received only coolly by Joe de Bruyn of the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association who said that there had been no consultation with the union by the Government. This is further evidence of the Prime Minister's rush to meet a political objective rather than a genuine need. Of course the SDA is the union for representing one of the largest industries for potential traineeships.

Apart from the attitude of the unions which have shown little compassion for the young unemployed-we do not see too many applications for trainee wages in logs of claims-the real problem is that the traineeships are not targeted to those particularly in need. The report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs-it is a good report-saw a need to target the scheme to disadvantaged youth. Under the Government's proposal confident kids, kids with initiative, kids from higher socio-economic backgrounds, kids whose parents have some clout in the business world, will get the traineeships. They are the kids who would have got training in any event; they are the kids who would have got jobs in any event. But the taxpayer is now to subsidise their employment and their parents and further subsidise their training. As we know, resources are not unlimited so those most in need of training-the disadvantaged youth-will miss out again.

The Government will continue the current six-month employment subsidy for the long term unemployed although we note from the Budget Papers that the figure will be reduced. That is very hard to follow. Why will the figure be reduced? Presumably it is because the Government wants the scheme to have the widest electoral appeal. Why pay employers? In Germany they are not paid. The dual system, where employers accept their responsibility for taking on trainees as part of their general social responsibility to society, works well. Presumably, the reason is to keep up the trainee wage in order to lessen union objection to a fear of trainees undercutting full time employment.

We support the concept of trainee wages. However, we believe that if they cannot be negotiated between employer and employee according to circumstances-that is the ideal, the best system, because some employment circumstances may require one, two or three years; some may require more time away from work, some less time away from work-they should be written into all awards which give all kids the chance to compete for traineeships. The government subsidy should then be targeted to the disadvantaged, who would otherwise be unlikely to gain traineeships.

The Government has been spending 70 per cent of the budget in this field on short term job creation and employer subsidies. We on this side of the chamber believe that the emphasis is all wrong. Some of the community employment program money might be fulfilling other social goals but it is not training kids or giving them a long term employment future. When I see CEP money spent in Adelaide to rip up a bitumen road and reapave it in brick, I despair. When I see money being spent on foreshore beautification in the Iron Triangle to help those who have lost their jobs in the steel industry as a result of structural change I think perhaps it is a worthwhile social goal but it is a confusion of goals if we are looking to give young people an opportunity for long term employment. I wonder why the Government cannot wake up.

We would like to see much more of that money going into universities, colleges of advanced education, technical and further education and, when necessary, supporting kids to be trained to their full potential. Mr Deputy President, as you know, statistics show that the better educated, the better trained a young person is, the better is his job potential. Therefore, we believe that a great opportunity has been lost to assist the young of this country. This leads me to Mr Bannon and his attempt, at public expense, to woo the voters on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah, now we know why you are on the speaking list.

—Senator Crowley should just wait patiently. Mr Bannon has announced programs to provide an extra 6,300 jobs of which, he said, 70 per cent would go to young people. The publicity literature that followed stated that all of the jobs-6,300-will go to young people. The State Budget Papers state:

SPEECH.PARA: Traineeships are an innovation to be introduced into South Australia in 1986. If that statement sounds familiar it is because it is taken from the Federal Budget Papers. There is no State initiative in this at all. In actual fact, the 1,600 jobs that he says he is going to create relate to a Commonwealth project. As I have suggested to honourable senators, by virtue of the inherent weaknesses of the Commonwealth scheme, they are jobs that would go to young people who would get jobs in any event.

If we go further through the State Budget Papers we see that Mr Bannon expects an extra 200 young people to take up benefits of the Commonwealth Government's program known as the experimental training program. That is surprising because the Commonwealth Budget figures show that the program is going to fund only 600 places for the whole of Australia. He talks about an extra 200 places for South Australia. One can be excused for having grave doubts about the reality of that situation. If one works through the programs, as I hope Senator Crowley has, one will see that Mr Bannon mentions in his Budget the steel regions assistance scheme, which, by the way, is being reduced; pre-vocational training; the group apprenticeship scheme; and the self-employment ventures scheme. In fact, if one adds up the totals, as I have done, and one takes into account the private enterprise schemes such as those that have been promoted by Rotary International, one still finds that one is about 3,000 jobs short on what Mr Bannon says his Budget contains. What it amounts to is that the youth and unemployed are being used as pawns in the Government's electioneering strategy.

There is very little the South Australian Government is contributing to the long term employment future of South Australia's young people. What South Australians will remember when it comes to a crunch on election day is that despite all the hype about skills, training and employment, the Bannon Government has cut the funding for technical and further education in real terms in 1985-86. It is not surprising that the highest level of unemployment of all the mainland States is to be found in South Australia at the moment-a level of 22.6 per cent. The South Australian handout says:
What about me?
YES is the answer.
If you're young and unemployed and wondering where to turn, you'll be glad to know there's someone who can offer some positive answers.
YES.
YES-Youth Employment Schemes-is busy creating 6,300 new employment and training positions for young people.

That is not true. It is time governments stopped misrepresenting the position. It is time they stopped using kids as political pawns. It is time they stopped wasting taxpayers' money on advertising campaigns for self-aggrandisement, particularly those which unfairly raise expectations. It is time they cut back on short term band-aid jobs which are primarily designed to improve the employment statistics. It is time that money saved went into greater educational opportunities, particularly in secondary schools and TAFE. It is time that greater support went to kids wanting to continue education but who are unable to afford to do so. To the extent that the Commonwealth package helps to do that, I applaud it. But it is too little too late.

The Kirby report reminds us that despite free tertiary education, there has been no improvement in access of the lower socio-economic groups to university training. It is time we allowed particular employers and particular employees to negotiate training agreements for young people. It is not beyond the wit of man to draw into that registration procedure to provide for protection if that is not necessary. It is time that all appropriate awards provided for training wages, terms and conditions. It is time that training subsidies the Government is going to provide on an across the board basis were redirected to disadvantaged youth. It is time that governments met their responsibility to employ their fair share of youth, particularly in training areas. This is a matter which Senator Harradine has raised very validly in this chamber before. No doubt he will do so again today. It is time the private sector was educated to its responsibility in the training challenge. Fancy paying Ansett Airlines of Australia $300,000 to induce it to take on 300 young trainees. Notwithstanding all the State support that Ansett receives, that company has to be induced by this further massive payment of taxpayers' money.

The Labor Government has not served Australia's young unemployed well. There have been too many promises, too many calls for praise, too little vision and too little achievement. What I have attempted to put very briefly in this short presentation is the coalition's alternative approach which we believe is more realistic and will at least give the young people of Australia an opportunity to be trained for the work which they so readily deserve to be able to undertake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of youth unemployment is indeed a matter of public importance. It is a matter of concern which has been expressed by all sides of this Parliament. That concern, of course, is not only evident in terms of the strain placed on the Budget by the cost of unemployment but also in terms of the cost to individuals. The total cost to the Commonwealth of unemployment in 1985-86 will be in the vicinity of $5.5 billion. That amount will pale into insignificance when it is compared with the cost to the individual unemployed themselves, their families and the cost in terms of the social disruption and dislocation of Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder, then, that the Government has embarked on the program Priority One: Young Australia. I would have thought that a real test of whether the Government has made young Australians priority one would be to examine what the Government is doing in the area in which it can have the most effect, and that is in the area of the Commonwealth Public Service. After all, the Government has a direct responsibility for that area. The fact is that in this International Year of Youth in which the Government has said that young Australia is priority one, the most recent figures released by the Australian Public Service Board show that youth employment in the Australian Public Service has fallen to an all time low. The fact is, according to the latest figures issued by the Public Service Board, that young people under 21 years of age constitute only 6.3 per cent of Australian Public Service staff. That compares with 22.6 per cent in 1966. Clearly, this tragic state of affairs for youth has been brought about by deliberate policy decisions, which still remain in force, denying youth, particularly girls, their fair share of Public Service jobs. The fact is that if the Government is serious about Priority One: Young Australia it must do something in the area for which it alone has responsibility.

I congratulate the Government for initiating Priority One: Young Australia. I look forward to some statement by the Government as to what it is going to do to rectify the tragic state of affairs that is taking place in each and every one of the departments for which each and every one of the Ministers are responsible. By the way, the statistic that I have just referred to puts paid to the main thrust of the Opposition's proposal to cut youth wages. Cutting youth wages appears to be the major thrust of its proposed solution to the problem. But the fact is that youth wages in the Public Service as a percentage of adult wages have hardly changed in the last 20 years. They have made no difference whatsoever. They have not contributed one iota to the serious decline in youth employment in the Public Service. As was said by Senator Cook earlier, the Opposition has not one scintilla of empirical evidence to show that the level of youth wages is contributing to youth unemployment.

I go to the matter of shop assistants' wages. What does the Opposition expect young people to live on? A 17-year-old shop assistant receives a net pay of $128 a week and at the end of the year of course has to pay the Medicare levy. If one takes into account the fact that shop assistants have to dress for the public, take themselves to and from work and pay board, they are really hardly any better off than they would be if they were on the dole. Let us face the facts about this. It is a poor panacea to say: `Cut youth wages and we will increase jobs'. It is important that we concentrate on training youth because employers have been spoilt; they have been able to pick and choose in the labour market. It is also important to give young people work experience, and to that extent what the Government is proposing is important. I will be interested to see what Senator Siddons is proposing as well. The essence of the matter is that we have to recognise that youth unemployment has a social as well as an economic aspect. The plain fact is that there are more people in or seeking paid work than there are jobs available. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his John Curtin Memorial Lecture in September 1983:

The plain fact is that no Government in Australia will now, or in the forseeable future, solve the problem of unemployment solely through the available methods of increasing the supply of jobs. At least equal attention must be paid to the question of reducing the demands for jobs by helping to provide socially constructive alternatives.

What more socially constructive alternative is there than the care and supervision of children at home? Whether the wife or the husband provides that care and attention is beside the point. One of the major problems that we face today is that many families are forced to have both partners out in the work force because they cannot make ends meet. Budgetary policies must be designed to protect the one-income family and to ensure that that family has the true freedom of choice to engage in that socially constructive alternative of caring for and supporting their children at home. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this afternoon a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to give real priority to the issues of youth employment.

This matter was proposed by the Opposition and has already been spoken to by a number of Opposition members. I waited in vain to hear the issue debated seriously by Senator Vanstone, the proposer, but I was unable to obtain from that contribution very much in the way of elucidation about what exactly the Opposition would do given the opportunity. Nor was I able to hear from that contribution any acknowledgment of the Opposition's role in developing the state in which we now find ourselves in Australia. We have a very serious social problem which sees up to 100,000 young people leaving school each year and seeking employment without the vocational preparation which is necessary for them to ensure employment.

Rather than take the approach of the coalition, which when it was in government produced a number of ad hoc, hastily cobbled together, completely inefficient and inadequate schemes to try to boost employment, the Australian Labor Party has approached the matter very carefully and has finally put together a cohesive approach as a result of a number of very thorough studies which has been done in conjunction with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development-a report by the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs and a review of youth support schemes, just to mention a few of the preparations which we made for this very important task.

The Australian tradition of early school leaving ages compares very poorly, as we have heard this afternoon, with west European and Scandinavian countries, where the provision for education and other forms of support provide a safety net for young people until they are well past the ages of 15, 16 or 17, at which age in Australia it has been traditional for them to be cast out of the nest, as it were. In response to a question earlier this afternoon the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) explained that in most western European countries and in northern America it is common for young people to stay at school until they are 18 or 19, but in Australia the record has been very poor indeed.

By taking up the recommendations of the Kirby report on training, and rationalising youth payments, we have initiated a number of measures which we confidently anticipate will have a profound and positive influence on the life and career chances of 16- and 17-year-old young Australian people. Important elements will operate to achieve this. Firstly, we can assume that, with the increase of secondary allowances, secondary education participation will continue to rise towards the goal suggested by the Karmel Quality of Education Review Committee. Secondly, we have targeted 1988 as the date by which our traineeship system is to be fully developed. With a decline in this age group as a proportion of the population we anticipate that very few 16- and 17-year-olds need face the prospect of unemployment by the 1990s. In addition, there should be a noticeable reduction in the unemployment rates of 18- and 19-year-olds as the traineeship proposal is extended to older age groups.

We were questioned earlier in this debate about the implementation of our new traineeship program and I remind the Senate that we really have not been very tardy about this. The announcement was made by the Prime Minister in mid-August. By 25 September agreement had already been reached with Western Australia for a proposal involving 500 trainees. By 2 October the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) was able to announce a traineeship with Ansett Airlines of Australia. It will provide for an initial recruitment of about 80 young people as trainees, and it is expected within 12 months to employ 300 young people under the scheme. By 16 October, which is today-less than two months after the initial announcement of the scheme-we are told that already there are 36 group proposals before the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, varying from some that are very small to some that are very large. I do not believe we have been dragging our feet at all on this and I imagine that we may in fact have created an all time record for the implementation of a program.

From the outset, however, we are hoping that all school leavers will be eligible for this scheme although, as the Prime Minister said in his statement, 16- and 17-year-olds will have the highest priority, especially those young people who have not completed Year 12. We focus upon this group which is educationally and often socially and economically most in need of attention and most at risk.

A traineeship involves an agreement between an employer and an employee for the provision of training to achieve particular skills. A system of certification is also included in the scheme. This does not replace the apprenticeship system but will cater for industries where on the job training can be greatly enhanced by approved off the job training. Initially, this will involve the finance, retail and tourism industries. I am taking this opportunity to explain the scheme, realising that many people will be interested to hear details of how it will operate. The trainee is to be paid by the employer at a wage agreed between trade unions and employers, but it will be at least $90 a week.

I thank Senator Harradine for his contribution which very clearly analysed the position of poorly paid 16- and 17-year-olds, very many of whom have no security, no prospect of advancement and get very little in the way of training. These traineeships will run for a minimum of 12 months. In that period, at least 13 weeks must be spent in approved off the job training-usually one day a week. Training will be conducted by accredited authorities, predominantly in technical and further education, but private courses may be accredited if they satisfy the State Industrial Training Division, which is a tripartite organisation including representatives of TAFE and other training authorities.

We were questioned earlier about how TAFE could possibly cope. It will cope very well. After years of neglect by Federal and State conservative governments, TAFE is beginning to bloom. This scheme will assist in the development of the real contribution that TAFE can make to the community outside its traditional role. The TAFE colleges will be substantially compensated for involvement in the scheme. The money awarded, $1,700 per placement, may be used for either capital or recurrent funding. A review is already under way to see what extra capital funding will be required in the event that the system is overstretched. In the short term, TAFE in my State of Western Australia is apparently capable of coping with the 1985-86 target number and is well on the way to filling the 2,500 traineeships included in a recently announced youth package for that State. I am happy to report that I have just discovered that Western Australia has the highest secondary retention rate in the nation.

There are clear advantages for employers in the scheme. Every effort is being made to simplify procedures, recognising that the paperwork involved has acted as a deterrent in employment schemes in the past. State and Commonwealth governments have co-operated in this scheme so that one stop shopping caters for the requirements of both. Unlike apprenticeship formalities which, I understand, go to about 12 or 14 different pieces of documentation, only two forms need to be completed. One is an application to become an approved employer of one or a number of trainees and the other is in order for an agreement to be registered. Many employers will already have been approached and will know that the Commonwealth Government will provide training fees to the employer both for the training required on the job and for the off the job training part of the program.

In many cases, employers have already responded. As I said earlier, I understand that 36 group proposals, ranging from quite small to large, are now before the Department. The Ansett Airlines proposal has been read about, I think, by all honourable senators and is seen as a model for a group training scheme. Young people who are interested in the scheme can get detailed information from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations traineeship committees, the Commonwealth Employment Service, schools, TAFE institutions, colleges, CES careers reference centres, youth organisations and from State departments of labour. One very important feature of the scheme is that consumers or clients-the trainees and employers-will together make the decisions about the training components of this system, advised of course, by relevant trade union and education authorities as necessary.

The scheme has the capacity to tailor the formal and informal training to the needs of the individual. Training may be broadly based and have transferrable as well as occupational skills, the aim being to enable young people to become adaptable as well as productive. Equal participation of women is an objective of the new system. Special attention is also to be given to particularly disadvantaged young people, including Aboriginals, the long term unemployed, those with disabilities and non-English speaking migrants. Up to 15 per cent of traineeships will be reserved for such special cases, who tend to have missed out badly in the less thoughtfully designed schemes established by the previous Government.

Traineeships will help give young people a foothold in the labour market, enabling them to build up skills and experiences across a wider range of industries than do apprenticeships, and more equitably between the sexes. By developing a capacity to cope with change they will contribute to increased competitiveness in the longer term and a greater likelihood of achieving sustained high rates of growth which will, in turn, speed the reduction in youth unemployment.
